The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators, which is the mathematical foundation of quantum mechanics. Our characterization is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our results provide a mathematical foundation for the program of reconciling quantum theory with mathematics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic assemblies for two myxozoan species, and we compare these to the genome and transcriptome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of extreme degeneration of the cnidarian body plan. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of the parasitic lifestyle. (Show more)

The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion people by the middle of the 21st century. Meeting the food demand of this large population will become increasingly challenging as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. We quantify how the variability of maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The coexistence of diverse species is a fundamental challenge of ecology. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the diet breadth, composition, and overlap of seven large mammalian herbivores (five wild, one domestic) in a semiarid African savanna. We found that the degree of overlap in diet composition was greater than the degree of overlap in diet breadth, and that the degree of overlap in diet composition was greater than the degree of overlap in diet breadth. These results suggest that the coexistence of large mammalian herbivores in a given ecosystem may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the mechanisms that promote biodiversity and for the management of large mammalian herbivores.

We surveyed more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States about their experiences with the COVID-19 crisis. Our findings suggest that the crisis is already having a devastating impact on small businesses. Many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are also financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the total load is far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of the plastic debris by the food webs and the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the Solar System is one of the most important questions in science. We determined the age of presolar silicon carbide grains, which are the products of the Big Bang and the first generations of stars, and are the oldest objects in the Solar System.

The expansion of the global fishing fleet has been driven by the development of the motorized sector, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The powered-artisanal fleet has grown from 1.5 to 2.5 million vessels, and the motorized fleet has grown from 1.2 to 2.5 million vessels. The powered-artisanal fleet has increased its engine power by a factor of 6, while the industrial fleet has increased its engine power by a factor of 10. The powered-artisanal fleet has been the main driver of the increase in engine power, but it has also been the main driver of the decline in effective CPUE. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most vulnerable to the effects of climate change, and its expansion is likely to be limited by the availability of suitable fishing grounds.

The ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother is a key factor in the success of all species. Here, we show that the practice of allonursing, the sharing of maternal resources with the offspring, is the most effective way to increase reproductive output.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for a wide range of functions. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells, and the cells are connected by a network of connections. The network is highly connected, and the cells are connected to each other in a short-path manner. The network is also highly dynamic, and the cells are able to synchronize their activities. These properties are important for the endothelium to control the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of a data API that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The data are available at no cost and are expected to be useful to a wide range of stakeholders. We hope that the data and software will be useful to the research community and that the API will serve as a platform for future research and development.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of a large number of drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the channel’s selectivity. It is also the site of the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the proper functioning of the channel. Finally, we have demonstrated that the collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter can lead to the structural transition of the channel from a nonconductive and deep inactivated state to a conductive and open state. This work provides a better understanding of the structure and function of potassium channels. It also provides a new perspective on the mechanism of C-type inactivation. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of potassium channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for health. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood. Here, we identify a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi and are likely to be secreted into the gut lumen. These fungi could be used as a source of natural products for the development of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in dyadic encounters, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses under large deformation is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures with multiple material phases that seamlessly collaborate to produce target responses. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, is expressed in the erythroid lineage and plays a role in the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of effective therapies, the survival rate of cancer patients remains low. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. We found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that the suppression of SREBP1 or the inhibition of ferroptosis sensitized cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. These findings suggest that the combination of ferroptosis induction with mTORC1 inhibition may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. However, these drugs are associated with a high risk of developing heart failure. Our study reveals a mechanism of action of these drugs, which is the activation of a store-operated Ca2+ channel. This finding may lead to the development of new drugs with a lower risk of developing heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy failed to halt the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. This failure is partly due to the creation of early-seral ecosystems on private lands, which may have reduced the amount of older forest available for conservation. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will be critical to ensure the long-term persistence of the many species that depend on older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge. We present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics. We show that the predicted best candidate is more active than telithromycin, the only approved acylide antibiotic, and that it is more accessible, exhibits higher solubility, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach presented here can be used to identify new antibiotics for the treatment of antibiotic-resistant infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and can be used for a wide range of problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many applications.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of these devices can have a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime phase-delay the circadian clock, suppress melatonin, and reduce alertness the following morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1.2- to 1.4-ka period of global climate change. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of the magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. This is associated with a preferential expansion of Treg cells, but also with the induction of autoantibodies and organ-specific autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We present a comprehensive analysis of the phylogeny and evolution of beetle genes, including those involved in digestion of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, and reveal that the evolution of specialized herbivores was triggered by convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our findings have implications for the design of experiments and the interpretation of results in the field of cultural evolution. They also have implications for the design of technology in the real world.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the seventh leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is testable in animal models. These studies may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase under the conditions of the inner core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our findings provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its evolution. They also have implications for the formation of other dense planetary cores. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex cognitive skill we have. How the human brain processes language is therefore a fundamental question in cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can be used to understand the human brain’s processing of language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to find a stable solution to a problem or due to its ability to find a solution that is arbitrarily close to the true solution. We show that there are problems where, even if a stable solution exists, there is no algorithm that can find it. Our results provide a classification theory of the conditions under which stable NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the success of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a textbook example of exponential growth. Yet, the pandemic is also a textbook example of the failure of people to understand exponential growth. This article discusses the failure to recognize the experiment’s design flaws, which led to the erroneous conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth. The article also discusses the implications of this case study for the study of human cognition and the study of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are closely related but have different hosts and different pathogenic mechanisms. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has lost several enzymes required for amino acid synthesis, and that M. leprae has a defective heme pathway. M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA than M. leprae, and a Bayesian dating analysis suggests that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 13.9 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy bacilli and may lead to the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to thermodynamics, which is the study of the macroscopic properties of isolated systems. However, the entanglement and entropy of interacting systems are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a major step forward in the study of the thermodynamics of interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency. To combat the pandemic, a vaccine is needed. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is highly attenuated and protects hamsters from lethal challenge with wild-type virus. This vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive, which is a desirable property for a vaccine. It is also easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C. These properties make COVI-VAC a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was characterized by high mortality and recurrent epidemics. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe. This study challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats and provides new insights into the history of plague in Europe. Our results suggest that human ectoparasites were the primary transmission pathway for plague during the Second Pandemic. This study also provides a new perspective on the history of plague, which is still poorly understood.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, it is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. We also show that the evolution of the number of neurons is a major factor in the evolution of brain size and cognitive capacity.

TRAP1 is a member of the HSP90 chaperone family, and is thought to be a tumor suppressor. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer. (Show more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by severing filaments, but the mechanism is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF binds to filaments and, surprisingly, that the filament’s mechanical state does not affect this binding. However, we find that ADF binds more strongly to filaments that are twisted, and that this binding is enhanced by twisting. We propose that this mechanism increases the severing rate constant by 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in the food supply. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on brain and behavior and may help to explain the increased consumption of fructose-sweetened beverages and foods in the United States and elsewhere.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the history of the island in a way that was not possible before. We find that Madagascar was settled by two different waves, one from Africa and one from Asia, and that the settlement was not a homogeneous process across the island. This study provides a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. It also provides a better understanding of the history of the Indian Ocean and the role of Madagascar in this history.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This finding has implications for our understanding of the role of social media in our lives, as well as the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into a protein. The mRNA sequence is modified in a variety of ways, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis is not well understood. We have developed a method to study the effects of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis in a reconstituted translation system and human cells. Our work reveals that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and well-being, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders, and they are also evident in a longitudinal analysis, indicating that the feeling of worthwhile is a predictor of positive outcomes over time. The feeling that life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human upper respiratory tract is unknown. We show that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This mechanism is essential for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity.

The use of pesticides in agriculture is a major driver of biodiversity loss. However, the risk of pesticide contamination to surface water is not well understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. However, the role of animals in the spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of this trend, the problems that are being created, and the solutions that are needed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques and cell death. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are also involved in the immune response. We demonstrate that neurons are the source of a variety of potent inflammatory factors, which correlate with the extent of microgliosis. Moreover, we identify a unique neuron-specific inflammatory profile, which is absent in neighboring glial cells. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. We argue that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore predates the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of the domestic chicken and its spread across the Mediterranean world. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the knowledge of the steps involved is essential for understanding the role of the protein in the cell. This study adds a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results are important for understanding the role of the intermediates in the folding process and in the function of the protein in the cell. The study also provides a model for the study of the folding of large proteins. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the concentration of this class of molecules remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to be involved in the degradation of Np4-capped RNAs, also plays a major role in the decapping of other transcripts. This enzyme, which is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate, is able to decape Np4-capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to degrade other RNAs. This unique mode of action could have major implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although the immune system is activated in response to infection, it can become dysfunctional, leading to the development of a proinflammatory state that is associated with poor clinical outcomes. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We found that citrulline, a dietary amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study may also lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of other immune-mediated diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in a wide range of strain levels, and that the bandgap can be tuned by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to contribute to the development of diamond-based devices and applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. This study provides a structural and functional characterization of a unique peptide, which is a member of the NCR family of peptides. The structure of the peptide was solved by NMR spectroscopy, and the antifungal activity of the peptide was demonstrated in vitro and in vivo. The antifungal activity of the peptide was also demonstrated against plant fungal pathogens. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the female reproductive tract contributes to the maturation of sperm. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and that they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping blood to clot. Mutations in VWF cause a common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to VWF switches the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The results are important for understanding the role of VWF in hemostasis and for the development of new therapies.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that are essential to human health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, and shows that viruses are associated with a wide range of diseases. This study is a major step forward in understanding the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models due to the complexity of the process. The dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) is introduced to investigate the ACI process. The instrument is able to measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously, which is not possible with current remote-sensing techniques. The instrument was deployed in Beijing, China, to conduct observations. The observations show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is inferred to have decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channel C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help us understand the mechanism of BK channel function and may provide a new target for drug development. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the human red blood cell (RBC), the target of the disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a specific antigen on the parasite surface to bind to the surface of the RBC, which alters the biophysical properties of the RBC. This change in the RBC properties allows the parasite to invade the cell more easily. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This could have implications for the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in a wide range of strain levels, and that the bandgap can be tuned by strain. We also show that the bandgap can be completely closed by strain, without phonon instability. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of interferon-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza infection. These insights may lead to the development of strategies

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain is unknown. Here, we show that the brain encodes the merge operation as a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a neural implementation of the merge operation. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to identify the structure of sentences. This parser is likely to be important for understanding the structure of the world around us.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and homeostasis. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its function is well characterized. However, the mechanisms by which the function of the two isoforms of Axin are regulated are not well understood. We show here that the two isoforms are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, and that the regulation is tissue specific. This finding may be important for understanding the function of redundant genes in vertebrates.

This study provides a detailed characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to the development of obesity. The lateral hypothalamus is a brain region that is involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of this region causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this circuit is involved in the development of overeating and may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for plant-controlled nitrogen fixation that allows for the precise timing and location of nitrogenase activity in the plant root. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in agriculture, and it could also be used to develop new strategies for the delivery of nitrogen to plants in the field. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management. However, the program’s impact on forest outcomes may be limited by the fact that the program’s monitors are perceived as new authorities with influence over forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. Vaccine development has been accelerated, and several vaccines are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. This study reports the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells, that exhibits high-yield manufacturability, high-affinity binding to ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity after a single dose in mice compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. This engineered RBD may be used to design a vaccine or as a component of a VLP vaccine. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results provide a promising approach for the development of a vaccine against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. Although the majority of neuroblastoma patients is cured by surgery and chemotherapy, the disease remains one of the most aggressive pediatric cancers with a high mortality rate. In the present study, we provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKAL proteins in the development of neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from its progenitor Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is one of the most dramatic events in the history of microbiology. We present 17 genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which provide a snapshot of the pathogen’s evolution during this critical period. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not yet adapted to the flea and that it was not yet widespread across Eurasia. These data provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s evolution and ecology during its formative years. This information is critical for understanding the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in explaining support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to massive losses of soil carbon. However, the effects of alternative management practices on soil carbon storage and the structure and function of the soil microbial community are not well understood. We show that the management of agricultural lands can have a significant impact on soil carbon storage and the structure and function of the soil microbial community. These results have implications for the design of climate-smart agricultural practices and the development of policies to mitigate climate change. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for spillover and developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to estimate the risk of viruses with unknown origins spreading to humans. We validated the risk assessment using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 viruses ranked by the risk assessment were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. We capitalized on the recent wealth of virus discovery data to systematically identify and prioritize targets for investigation. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is often used as a proxy for the color of the reward, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a similar red nectar in Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited species. Our findings suggest that the red nectar trait is convergent and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in plant–pollinator interactions.

We present a study of the genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD). We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly of northern and central European origin, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is also reflected in the functional variants that we identified, which indicate that women with artificial skull deformations may have differed in visible characteristics. Our results suggest that the genetic history of Europe during the Migration Period was more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a pathogen that currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and its potential for future outbreaks. They also suggest that the use of DPP

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated fever is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. We show that next-generation sequencing of pathogen RNA can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. This approach is resource-efficient, cost-effective, and can be deployed in resource-scarce settings. The identification of a variety of pathogens, including chikungunya virus, suggests that ongoing pathogen surveillance is needed to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated fever and deploy rapid public health response. This work is a step toward the development of a rapid pathogen surveillance system for undifferentiated fever in resource-scarce settings.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. The lagging strand template is replicated by the pol δ polymerase, which is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in eukaryotic DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme in other organisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. The RNA world hypothesis proposes that life may have evolved before the appearance of proteins. In this study, we used directed evolution to improve the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which is the molecular basis of RNA replication in the RNA world. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time and to identify neighborhoods that are likely to experience improvements. This information can be used to inform urban planning and to improve the quality of life in cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the immune characteristics were identified. The results show that the immune system was suppressed, and the inflammatory monocytes and T cells were activated. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, was given to severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and the results show that it is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanides, and the role of these compounds in the interaction with competing microbes, is described here.

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature polymorph, in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a rare mineral in the solar system. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock is also important because it provides evidence for the presence of high-temperature conditions in the sediment source region and/or at the time of deposition. The sedimentary rock is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, indicating that the source region was a single location. The sedimentary rock is also consistent with the “Lake Gale” model for the origin of the sedimentary rocks in Gale crater.
Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of agricultural and forestry systems. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate change.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of the development of Th1-like cells from Th17 precursors is unknown. Here we show that the development of Th1-like cells is required for the development of colitis and that this process requires the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is not fully understood. Here, we report a rapid and highly reproducible method to convert adult human fibroblasts to induced astrocytes. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This approach will accelerate ALS research and development of therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the tick microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the pathogen. We also show that the antifreeze glycoprotein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the arthropod microbiome and may lead to the development of strategies to control the transmission of infectious diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most iconic and enigmatic stories in vertebrate paleontology. The discovery of a basal member of the group that lost its tail (Pygostylia) provides new insights into the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without understanding the behavior of its components. In this paper, we show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity of the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. This color diversity is the result of the absorption of light by pigments in the skin. However, some animals, such as frogs, are green because of the presence of a pigment called biliverdin, which absorbs blue light. This study describes the molecular and functional basis of this phenomenon, which is the result of the presence of a protein that binds biliverdin. This protein is the first of its kind to be described in vertebrates and introduces a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and the role of serpins in the diversification of vertebrate color. This study also provides a new tool for the study of serpins and their functions. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with the development of breast cancer. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia regulates breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are not well understood. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which increases the percentage of BCSCs and NANOG mRNA levels. NANOG mRNA methylation is decreased by ALKBH5, NANOG protein levels are increased, and the BCSC phenotype is enhanced. Thus, ALKBH5 is a key regulator of BCSC phenotype in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a method that allows the identification of the animal origin of parchment without the need for invasive sampling. We show that the use of fetal animal skins for parchment is not necessary to produce the tissue-thin parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion.
