The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against the environment. It is essential to maintain intestinal homeostasis to prevent the development of inflammatory diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying intestinal inflammation remain largely unknown. Here, we report that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the pathogenesis of IBD and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion with the viral membrane. This work provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in 2020, the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we propose a new way to understand the chemical properties of atoms, which is based on the pressure dependence of these properties. We show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and we propose a new way to understand the chemistry of compounds. This work is a major advance in the field of chemical physics.

We show that human demography, rather than climate, is the main driver of changes in global fire activity. This has implications for the future of the global carbon cycle, as well as for the role of fire in ecosystem functioning. We find that, although climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are important, they are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts, Vibrio fischeri, through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts only at night, when the squid is producing light, and is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic crypts. This process is likely to be conserved in other animal–microbe associations, and it may be a general mechanism for the regulation of symbiont activities.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that this method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics were the result of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis provides evidence for the existence of no permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Instead, the Black Death was likely introduced into Europe several times, each time with a delay of 15 y. This finding has implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the second plague pandemic. It also suggests that the Black Death was not a one-time event, but rather a series of events. This hypothesis is supported by the existence of a second peak in the second plague pandemic, which started in the 1420s.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine ecosystem, but their population dynamics are poorly understood. Here, we provide evidence that a densovirus is the cause of a disease that has led to the mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus causing a disease in sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP; IL1R3) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the history of the island in a way that was not possible before. We find that Madagascar was colonized by different groups of people from Africa and Asia, with a sex bias in the colonization from Africa. The colonization happened recently, within the last few centuries, and the genetic structure is already detectable.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. We also show that the RNA base pairs with two genes and interferes with their regulation. These observations demonstrate that the protein and RNA compete for the same binding sites and that the protein can interfere with the action of the RNA. This is an example of a protein that has evolved to have a dual function. The protein may have evolved to have a regulatory function, but the regulatory function may have been lost and the protein now has a different function. This is an example of convergent evolution.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of effective vaccines and therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 variants and other viruses.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which collects expert assessments of crop status on a weekly basis, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We show that the CPC reflects the subjective perception of many surveyors at different locations, but that the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert assessments in quantitative analyses of agricultural production. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the history of life, and the molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolution of the plastid genome is a dynamic process, and that the molecular signature of the transition to obligate parasitism is not a simple loss of function. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of the plastid genome and its role in the evolution of life on Earth.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the world’s most famous nuclear test is a remarkable event. The material, which is a quasicrystal, was formed by the fusion of sand, copper, and concrete during the first nuclear explosion. The discovery of this material, which is the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, provides a unique window into the history of the discovery of quasicrystals and the conditions under which they form.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. These enzymes are required for the formation of the fifth ring, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of multiple sclerosis. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for multiple sclerosis. The 2012–2014 California drought is one of the most extreme droughts in the historical record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to anthropogenic warming.

Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder with a complex etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the core autistic symptoms and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies for autism. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disease characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1, the proteins that mediate store-operated Ca2+ entry, are associated with this disease. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated store-operated Ca2+ entry, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also advances our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates causes neuronal death. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of synaptic vesicles with the cell body. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein has the potential to facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the control of viral infections. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth. One-carbon units are essential for cell growth, and are generated by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in mice blocks tumor growth. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, and show that it blocks tumor growth in a cancer cell-line screen. Finally, we show that formate, a one-carbon donor, is a potent inhibitor of SHMT1/2, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These studies provide a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT1/2, and for the development of targeted therapies for cancer and lymphoma. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. Here, we show that the proteins that are part of the inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystals are designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals are expected to be scalable to larger dimensions, and the device configuration can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic and may have played a major role in the diversification of some lineages.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using sequences from modern viruses. However, viruses are known to have existed for millions of years, and it is important to study the evolution of viruses over long periods of time. Here we present the genomes of five ancient B19V viruses, which are phylogenetically related to the most common B19V genotype today. We also show that the rate of evolution of B19V is much lower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This acceleration is a strong indication that the climate is changing, and that the change is due to human activities.

Pain is a common and costly part of life. We show that, in America today, pain is less common and less severe for those in midlife than for those in old age. This is a mystery of American pain. We show that the gap between the pain of the more and less educated has widened in each successive birth cohort. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction intermediate is a key determinant of the reaction pathway and the rate and stereoselectivity of the reaction. The structure of the intermediate is also a critical component for understanding the mechanism of the reaction. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The structure of the intermediate is used to understand the reaction pathway and the stereoselectivity of the reaction. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) remains a severe and lethal disease, with a high case fatality rate. The development of effective antiviral treatments is therefore a high priority. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the development of a clinical trial to test the efficacy of remdesivir in MERS patients. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts only at night, when the squid is producing light, and is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic crypts. This process is likely to be conserved in other animal–microbe associations, and it may be a general mechanism for the regulation of symbiont activities.

This study is about the importance of teachers’ mindsets about discipline. It shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention, and that this change can have major effects on the quality of teacher–student relationships and student behavior.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of the genome. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity checkpoints. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe pneumonia with high mortality. The virus infects human cells by binding to cell receptors and fusing the virus envelope with the cell membrane. The virus spike (S) glycoproteins are cleaved sequentially during their secretion from virus-producing cells and after binding to target-cell receptors. Here, we show that the first S cleavage is required for MERS-CoV infection of human lung-derived cells, but not of other cell types. These findings suggest that the first S cleavage is important for MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a major cause of disease. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can have a large impact on meal selection behavior. This has the potential to make a significant contribution to the fight against climate change and the prevention of diet-related disease.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, and KRAS. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant step toward understanding the cell surface in cancer. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail programs are not likely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health crisis. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is unknown. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is not present in SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, and a unique dimerization interface that is not present in SARS-CoV. These unique interfaces may mediate unique immune suppression and evasion activities. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 disease and may lead to the development of therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and neuronal apoptosis in cultured cortical neurons. We also show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from the past. We can learn from the results of past experiments, and we can learn from the results of past observations. But what if we have a new experiment or a new observation that is different from anything that has been done before? How do we assess the strength of the evidence that it provides? This paper describes a new approach to this problem, which we call selective inference. It is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring a significant association than we would have done in the past. We illustrate the use of this approach in a number of common statistical methods. This approach will be important in the era of big data.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step for the formation of functional vascular networks. However, the development of ECs is not well understood, especially in the context of human development. Here, we show that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the development of vascular ECs. Our study provides a new approach for the development of vascular ECs and may lead to the development of a new therapeutic approach for vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of ALK and Ltk in development and cancer has been extensively studied. However, the physiological function of augmentors, which are the physiological ligands of ALK, has not been characterized. Here, we show that augmentors are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning. We also demonstrate that augmentors are essential for iridophore formation in the eye and body, but not in the skin. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentors and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentors are essential for iridophore differentiation in a tissue-specific context. These findings provide insights into the physiological function of augmentors and the role of ALK in development and cancer. They also provide a foundation for future studies on the role of augmentors in human health.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem. Although insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases for T2D, the molecular mechanisms underlying these two processes are still unclear. Herein, we found that STING, a key molecule in the innate immune system, plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. More importantly, STING deficiency causes T2D due to impaired insulin secretion. These findings establish a pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a new perspective for the development of therapeutic strategies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The packaging of their genome is a key step in the assembly of the virion. We identified a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. This mechanism is sequence dependent and involves a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. This study provides a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of influenza A virus genome packaging. It also suggests that the lack of conservation of this mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work could lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the disturbed flow in the arterial wall. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural and important part of the ecosystem in the United States. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires are the dominant cause of wildfires in the United States. Actions to reduce the risk of human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time and to study the causes of urban change. We hope that our method will be useful to researchers and practitioners interested in urban change.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropod pests remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a natural repellent receptor, which is absent in insects. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents and a new perspective for the rational design of insect control strategy. It should also help the conservation of biodiversity. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. Coral bleaching is a natural phenomenon that occurs when corals shed their symbiotic zooxanthellae in response to environmental stress. However, the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is not reversible, and the loss of zooxanthellae is often irreversible. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the stability of the coral holobiont in the face of climate change. This may ultimately help us to safeguard the functioning of the coral–algal symbiosis and the services it provides to humans.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the immune system. In this study, we show that the intestinal tumorigenesis in Drosophila leads to a dysregulation of the microbiome, which in turn triggers a regenerative response and promotes tumor growth. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, and it highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the understanding of intestinal tumorigenesis and for the development of therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. We found that the expression of the ROR1 receptor is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. This increase in ROR1 expression is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are important in the regulation of stemness. We also found that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. Finally, treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is still a matter of debate. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and marked climate and circulation changes in the Southern Hemisphere.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and policy. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that the majority of catches come from regions with high stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the high dependence of poor and undernourished populations on inland fisheries highlights the need to protect these resources from overfishing and degradation. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are the key to achieve high energy density and long cycle life. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult CNS are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular control of regeneration in the adult CNS and for developing new strategies for regenerative medicine.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and in the evolution of new traits. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a key determinant of the rate of evolution. Here, we describe the recombination landscape of a wild plant population.

The brain is a highly complex system, and the study of its organization is a major challenge. Here, we show that the resting organization of the brain can be directly measured in healthy and disease subjects, and that this information can be used to identify and characterize functional networks. This approach can be used to identify the organization of the brain in health and disease, and to monitor the effects of treatment.

The 5′ cap structure is the first modification added to messenger RNA (mRNA) and plays a central role in regulating mRNA stability and translation. The existence of 5′ modifications in RNA is now well established, but the nature of these modifications and their functional significance are still largely unknown. Here we describe the discovery of a 5′ NAD+ cap structure in yeast, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This finding expands the diversity of 5′ modifications and raises the possibility that the 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. These results also provide a foundation for future studies on the functional significance of 5′ NAD+ cap in eukaryotes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The study of epigenetic alterations in diabetes is of great interest because of the potential for epigenetic changes to be reversible. This study shows that epigenetic alterations in DNA methylation persist for several years in people with diabetes, and that these alterations are associated with glycemia. These findings support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of a cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a brain disorder, but the mechanisms involved in the development of the disease are not fully understood. Here we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it could be a previously unidentified target in the management of the disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a result of the production of a large number of volatile chemicals. These volatiles are produced during fruit ripening, and the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are not known. We have identified a gene essential for the production of a large number of these compounds, and we have shown that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also provides a model for understanding the biosynthesis of other classes of compounds in which the nitrogen atom is provided by a nonprotein source. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a map of local space, which is represented by grid cells, head-direction cells, border cells, and object-vector cells. How these cell types are organized anatomically is debated. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to examine the topographic arrangement of these neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and adjacent parasubiculum during unrestrained behavior. Our data suggest that grid cells are anatomically distinct from those of other cell types. These findings have implications for understanding the organization of the MEC map of space. They also provide a platform for future studies of the neural basis of navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not the only flowering signal in plants. FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal, which is able to induce flowering in distant hosts. This study provides a unique example of flowering regulation in plants, which is likely to be of interest to researchers in a variety of fields.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a new perspective on the function of the dopamine systems in health and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others. In this work, we show that the speed at which we respond to others is a signal of connection. This signal is used by others to assess the quality of our connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat and is the primary site of atrial fibrillation. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a regulator of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in Si accumulation and JA biosynthesis. These results suggest that Si may play a role in plant defense by priming JA-mediated defense responses. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the function of macrophages.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment locus of the DNA nanostructure determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work will be of interest to the plant biology and nanotechnology communities.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient inputs is unknown. We show that the majority of nutrient loading to Lake Michigan comes from a small number of large tributaries, but that the nutrient loads from small tributaries are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. These findings suggest that small tributaries may play a more important role in driving coastal nutrient inputs than previously appreciated. Our results highlight the need to address nutrient management in small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a fluctuating environment. We find that the network dynamics are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a fluctuating force and is constrained to be in a stable, far-from-equilibrium state.

This paper offers a mechanistic explanation for the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with an autoimmune encephalitis caused by antibodies against the NMDA receptor. The paper also offers a potential explanation for the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in this disease.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key driver of our understanding of the Earth system. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, especially for the Precambrian. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation. Certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate commitments to reduce this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been evaluated in a way that allows for a clear assessment of its effectiveness. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that the benefits are limited to areas that were already deforested before certification. Certification is also associated with reduced fire, but this effect is not mediated by deforestation. These findings suggest that certification is not yet having the impact needed to meet corporate commitments to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. However, the molecular mechanism of its regulation is not fully understood. Here, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex and provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process. This study also offers a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of sexual dimorphism, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study in developmental biology. Here we investigate the effects of sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in a model system, the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the genetic basis of sex determination in this species produces a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of sex-linked traits. In addition, the acquisition of a new sex determiner in a newly colonized population produces a variety of traits that are not linked to sex. These results suggest that the genetic basis of sex determination in M. mbenjii is capable of producing a variety of sexual phenotypes, and that the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles can have a major impact on the morphology and behavior of populations. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics may be a general feature of sex determination.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and photodegrading intermediates. We sought to understand the role of iron in the retina and found that iron levels in the retina are elevated in a vitamin A-depleted albino mouse model. This finding was supported by the observation that iron chelation reduced the oxidative degradation of the photoreceptor cell lipofuscin intermediates. These findings have implications for the retina, as well as for other tissues challenged by reactive oxygen species and photodegrading intermediates. This article is protected by copyright. Predators are the drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved modularity in their feeding structures, and that these structures have strong evolutionary associations with prey type. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization, and the role of morphological innovation in the diversification of food webs.

The human hand is a remarkable structure, with a suite of features that are only found in modern humans and Neandertals. These features are thought to have evolved over hundreds of thousands of years, but the timing and evolutionary context of their origin is unclear. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key feature of the human hand, was present in a Middle Pleistocene hominin fossil from Kenya. This provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived hand feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human form. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth. One-carbon units are essential for cell growth, and are generated by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks tumor growth in a colon cancer xenograft model. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, and show that it is effective in cellular models. Finally, we show that formate, a one-carbon donor, is a potent inhibitor of SHMT1/2, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These studies provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the resulting loss of natural habitats is a major threat to biodiversity. However, little is known about the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. We show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by fragmentation of forests. Our findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of modern agriculture, but at the same time, it has increased the weight of vehicles, which has led to compaction of the soil. We show that the weight of modern farm machinery has increased by a factor of 10, and that the weight of the largest farm vehicles is now approaching that of the sauropods, the largest animals that walked the Earth. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the largest sauropods, the brachiosaurs, had a fixed foraging trail that they followed for their entire life. This study highlights the need for a more stringent design of farm machinery to reduce the risk of subsoil compaction. The implications of this study are that the use of farm machinery may have had a significant impact on the evolution of the largest animals that walked the Earth. This hypothesis needs to be tested in the future.
